bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kîtahtawê , ayîsiyiniwak êh-pimipicicik , iskwêwak paskêwak , nânitaw nikotwâsik iskwêwak , ê-wîh-mônahikêcik mistaskosîmina . Once upon a time, when some people were on the trek, some women left the band, about six women, to dig wild turnips.
êkotah pêyak miyosiw iskwêw ; namoy âwiya onâpêma ôhtâwiya okâwiya pimâtisiyiwa . Among them was one beautiful woman; none of her people, husband, father, or mother, was living.
êkosi wîcihiwêw êyako . She went along, now, with the others.
êkwah tahki pimohtêwak , êh-mônahikêcik . They kept on walking and digging roots.
kîtahtawêh ê-pasâhcâyik , êkotah awa kâ-miyosit iskwêw mihcêt miskam mistaskosîminah , êh-mônahahk . Then presently, in a valley, this handsome woman found many wild turnips, and dug them up.
piyisk osâm kinwês ayâw . In the end she stayed too long.
namoya kiskêyihtam êh-nakatiht . She did not notice that she was left alone.
iyikohk êh-kiskêyihtahk , âsay pahkisimôw . By the time she noticed it, the sun was setting.
êkwa êh-sipwêhtêt , nam âwiya owîcêwâkana . So, when she went away from there, she had no companions.
êkos îsi sipwêhtêw . So she set out.
namoya kiskêyihtam tântêh êy-itohtêyit owîcêwâkana . She did not know whither her companions had gone.
kîtahtawêh oskinîkiwa ka-pêcâstamohtêyit . Then at one time she saw a young man coming toward her.
nîpawiw . She stood still.
otihtik . He came to where she was.
tânêhk ôma ? itik . “What is the matter?” he asked her.
miyosiyiwa ôh ôskinîkiwa . This youth was handsome.

êh-wanisiniyân , itaw ;
niwîcêwâkanak êh-nakasicik , itêw . “It is that I have lost my way,” she told him; “that my companions have left me,” she told him.

seg.gloss: “Is that so! If you want me to take you home, I will take you home.”
“Yes.

p.seg: namoya mâka nikwayask nika-kîh-itohtahison , itwêw aw îskwêw . But I shall not be able to find the way very well,” she said. LB on {nikwayask}: The speaker starts to compound {kwayask}: “properly” with the following verb. This is contrary to habit; he corrects himself by starting the verb all over again. I have often observed the same thing in Menomini, where a similar “incorporation” is permitted but awkward.

namoya ayisk kwayask isi-nisitohtawêw ,
nîkinâhk ê-wîh-isih-kîwêhtahit , êh-itêyihtahk ; For she did not understand him aright, and thought he was going to take her home to her dwelling;
mâka namoya : ôhôw oskinîkiwah wîkiwâyihk ê-wîh-itohtahikot . but no: it was to his people's home that the youth meant to take her.
êkosi kîwêhtahik , êh-pa-pmohtêcik . So he took her home with him; they walked on and on.
piyisk êh-tipiskâyik , mistah êh-tipiskâyik , kîtahtawêh kâ-wâpahtahk mîkiwâhp êh-misâyik . At last, at nightfall, when it was quite dark, she saw a large lodge.
êkoyikohk kiskêyihtam namoya wîkiwâhk êh-itohtêt aw îskwêw . Only then did she realize it was not to her people's dwelling she was going.
êkosi takohtêwak . So they reached the place.

êh-pîhtokêt ,
êhêhêhêhê ! k-êtwêyit pîsim ôhtâwiya ê-kisêyiniwiyit ; “When he entered, the Sun's father, who was an old man, said, “Dear me!
cêskwah , nikosis ! pitah nika-miyâhkasikân , itwêyiwa . Wait a bit, my son! Let me first burn incense,” he said.

êh-miyâhkasikêt ,
hâw , êkwah nistim ta-pîhtokêw , itwêyiwa . When he had lit the incense, “There, now let my daugher-in-law come in,” said he.
pîhtokêw aw îskwêw . She entered the lodge.

pôt ôhi kîh-wâpistikwanêyiwa kisêyiniwa êh-apiyit , kâ-wâpahtahk wêskwâhtêmihk nanâtohk kêkway êh-astêyikih , ayôwinisah , mînah ospwâkanak , asinîw-ospwakanak , mina wiyâkanihk êh-astêyikih mînisah êh-kîsitêyik . There she saw that white-headed was the old man who sat there, and she saw many kinds of things placed at the far end of the lodge, garments, and pipes, stone pipes, and stewed berries in the bowl.

êkosi ,
êhêhêy ! itwêw awa kisêyiniw ; Then, “Dear me!” said the old man;
âyiman , nikosis , kâ-pêsiwat nistim ! itwêyiwa ; “It is no easy thing, my son, that you have brought me a daughter-in-law!” he said;
kîkway kiy-âsamâyahk ? pikoh mînisah , itwêyiwa . “What can we give her to eat? Nothing but berries,” he said.
êkwa mînisah asamik . Then she was given berries to eat.
êh-kîsi-mîcit , kawisimôwak . When she had eaten them, they went to bed.

êh-mêkwâ-nipât , êh-waskawiyit onâpêma , âsay kâ-pêhtahk ,
nikosê , waniskâ ! While she was asleep, as her husband stirred, already she heard the old man call, “My son, get up! LB on {êh-waskawiyit}: One should expect “when he budged” to follow his father's call.

seg.gloss: Day is at hand!

p.seg: kipamihtâ kîsikâw ! k-êtwêyit kisêyiniwa . Do not forget that you take care of the day!”
isi-waniskâyiwa . At this her husband arose.
wîstah waniskâw , mîna mînisâpoy êh-otinamiyit , êh-asamikocik ôhi kisêyiniwa . She too got up, and again the old man took some berry stew and gave it them to eat.

kaskihtêwêkin otinamiyiwa , êkwah mihkwêkin iyikohk ka-têpipayiyik iskwêw t-ôtâsit ; êkwah papakiwayânêkin manipitamiyiwa . He took some black cloth, and enough red flannel to make a woman's leggings; and he tore off a length of cotton cloth.

hâ , nikosis , êyakonih ani nistim ta-kaskwâtamâsôw , itêw . “There, my son, even these let my daughter-in-law sew into garments for herself,” he told him. LB ad {ta-kaskwâtamâsôw}: For {kaskikwâtamâsôw}.
êkosih êh-kîsi-mîcisocik , ati-wayawîw awa oskinîkiw . then, when they had done eating, the young man went out.
êkwah awa aw îskwêw osîhtâw oskotâkay , kapê-kîsik êh-kaskikwâsot . Then the woman made a dress for herself, sewing all day.
mwêhci êh-pahkisimoyit , kîsikwâsôw , kâ-pê-pîhtokêyit owîkimâkana . Just as the sun set, she finished her sewing, and there, her husband came into the lodge.
yâh , miywêyihtam êh-pîhtokêyit . Oh, she was glad when he came in.
êkosi otah ayâw , nayêstaw mînisah êh-mîcicik . So she stayed there, and they ate only berries.

tâpwâ kîkisêpâ mâna êh-sipwêhtêyit onâpêma , kâ-kapê-kîsik namoya êh-takosiniyit , êyikohk pêhkisimoyiki , êh-pihtokêyit . And truly, her husband, leaving always in the morning, all day he would not arrive, but only at sunset would he come into the lodge.
êkosi namoya kiskêyihtam kêkwayah ôhi onâpêma mîn ôhi osisah . She did not know what manner of men were her husband and her father-in-law.
mistahi mâna kaskêyihtam , êkâ wîhkâc kotakah awiya êh-wâpamât . She often felt very lonely, for she never saw anyone else.

kîtahtawêh , êh-apit , êh-tipiskâk ,
nikosis , kiyîsikâkih ta-kîh-papâmohtêw nistim . Then at one time, as she sat there at nightfall, “My son, do allow my daughter-in-law to walk about during the day.
miyâmay kaskêyihtam , itêw okosisah . Surely she must feel lonely,” said the old man to his son.
êhag , itwêwiwa . “Very well,” he answered.

seg.q: ayisk kiyâna mîna kikîh-isih-pakitinikonâw kâ-tipêyihtahk kahkiyaw kêkway , ta-pamihtâyan askiy .
seg.gloss: “After all, as for you and me, we were created and set down by Him who orders all things; that you might take care of the earth.

p.seg:
niya êh-kîh-âyimêyihtamân ta-pamihtâyân ,
kiyâm wiya êy-osk-âyiwit t-âtoskawêw , kâ-kîh-itêyimitân ,
kôhtâwînaw ksê-manitôw , k-êtwâyit okosisah . When I found too hard the task of caring for it, ‘Let him, who is still young, do the work,’ I thought concerning you, ‘for our Father, the Great Manitou’,” said he to his son.

seg.q: hâw , niwîkimâkan , êkâ êpiyâni , kika-papâmohtân ôtah .
seg.gloss: “Well them, my wife, when I am not at home, you may walk about here.

p.seg: ôma mîna wâsakâm ay-ihtakonwa mistaskosîmina , itwêyiwa . Here too, round about there are wild turnips,” said he.

tâpwê êkosi tôtam ; kâ-sipwêhtêyici owîkimâkana , êkosi wîstah êh-papâmohtêt , êh-mônahahk mistaskosîminah . Then really she did so; when her husband had gone away, she too would walk about, digging wild turnips.

piyêtâcih , wêtâkosiniyikih , kâh-pâh-pîhtonahkih , itêh êh-apiyit osisah , êkotê êh-pakitinahk . When she brought them home in the evening, after peeling them, she would put them down where her father-in-law sat.
otinam mâna awa kisêyiniw , êh-nanâskomot . The old man would take them up and give thanks.
kâkikê ntakâwâtê ômatôwahk , osâm wâh-wîhkâc êh-asamikawiyân , itwêyiwa . “Always, you must know, I have longed for the like of these, for very seldom am I give them to eat,” he would say.

iyikohk pêhkisimoyiki , êh-pîhtokêyit onâpêma , êkosi êh-asamât , mistaskosîmina mîna mînisâpoy êh-mîcicik , nama kêkway pîtos êh-mîcicik . At sunset, when her husband came into the lodge, she would give him food, and they would eat wild turnips and berry stew, nothing else.

kîtahtawê têpiskâyiki ,
hâ , nikosis , miyâhkasikê ! êh-itwêyit , kâ-pê-yôhtênamoht , mâna mihkwêkin , âskaw kaskitêwêkin , âskaw papakiwayân , kikih-mînisâpoya , êh-pîhtokêtisinamoht , êkos êh-otinahk aw oskinîkiw . Then at times, when night had come, the old man would say, “Now, my son, burn some incense!” and the door of the young man's lodge would be opened, and red flannel, and sometimes black cloth, sometimes muslin together with dishes of berry stew, would be projected into his lodge, and the young man would take them up. merged two sentences
kîtahtawê kiskêyihtam aw îskwêw awâsisah ê-wîh-ayâwât . In time the woman knew that she was going to have a child.

seg.gloss: “Well, now never walk about;

p.seg: mâskôc kwayask wîh-wâpamâyahkoh awa awâsis , itik owîkimâkanah . let us hope that we may without mishap have sight of this child,” her husband told her.
namoy êkwah mônahikêw aw îskwêw ; ayisk kitahamâk owîkimâkana . no longer now did that woman dig roots; for her husband had forbidden it.

tâpwê piyisk nôhtê-wâpamêw ocawâsimisah , êh-âhkosit , êkwah ê-wîh-wâpamât ocawâsimisah . Really, in due time, she felt the need of having sight of her child, for she grew ill, being about to see her child.
êh-tipiskâyik , kâh-wâpamâcik , owîkimâkana êh-pamihikot . In the night they saw it, she and her husband, who was caring for her.
pôt ôhi nâpêsisah . It turned out to be a boy.
êkosi miyopayiw . Then she was well.

êkwah , â , mitonih ayôwinisah mihcêt ayâwak ; ayis namoya kôtaw-âpacihtâw aw îskwêw , ôhi ocawâsimisah êw-isi-pamihât ; ayisk wêyôtisiw awa kisêyiniw . Now, they had, oh, many clothes; for the woman did not lack whatever she would use in caring for that child of hers; for rich was that old man.

mistahi miywêyihtam awa kisêyiniw êh-oyôsisimit , êwako pâskac êh-kanawêyimât ôsisima , iyikohk êh-miywêyihtahk êh-oyôsisimit , The old man was very glad to have a grandchild and even tended the child himself, so glad was he to have a grandson,

âskaw piko êh-kanawêyimât aw îskwêw ocawâsimisah , êh-papâmohtêt , êh-papâmohtahât , êh-kaskêyihtahk mâna aw îskwêw , êkâ wîhkâc kotakah awiyah êh-wâpamât . and the woman only now and then took care of the child, walking about, taking the child about, for she was mostly sad at heart because she never saw any other people.

kîtahtawê êkwah êh-misikitiyit okosisah , êkwah êh-papâmohcêsiyit , kîtahtawê mâka mîna kîksêpâ ê-sipwêhtêyit onâpêma , wîstah sipwêhtêw , kontah êh-papâh-sâ-sâkêwêt . Then at one time, when her son had grown larger and was already walking a bit, then at one time, when her husband, as always, had gone forth early in the morning, she too went out, mounting at random over the crests of the hills.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahk mîkiwâhpis . Presently she saw a little lodge.
itohtêw . She went there.

êh-takohtêt ,
ta-tawâw , nôsisimis ! k-êtwêyit nôtokêsiwa . When she came to it, “Come in, my grandchild!” said an old woman.
pîhtokêw . She entered.
êêêy , nôhkom êcik âwa itah êh-ay-ayât , kâ-kaskêyihtamân mâna ! itêw ; “Goodness me, and so here is my grandmother living here, and I lonesome and sad all the while!” she said to her;

kayâs kîh-kiskêyimitân , ôtah êh-wîkiyin , kah-pêh-kâh-kiyôkâtin , nôhkô , iyikohk kâ-kaskêyihtamân mâna , itêw . “Long ago, if I had known that you were living here, I should have been coming to see you, lonesome and sad as I have been all the while,” she said to her.

seg.q: hêêy , nôsisê , kikiskêyihtên cî ôm îtah k-âyâyan ?
seg.gloss: “Dear me, grandchild, and do you know what place this is where you are?”

p.seg: nama wiya , itêw . “No,” she answered her.
ôtêh ôma nîhtaskamik ê-kîh-ohtohtêyan , kikiskêyimâ cî âna kâ-wîkimat ! itik . “And down there on the earth below, did you know who he was whom you have married?” the other asked her.
namoya , itêw . “No,” she answered her.

seg.gloss: “That which you as a mortal call ‘Sun,’ even such is he.

seg.q: êyakw anim ôhci kâ-kapê-kîsik êkâ k-ôh-apit ;
seg.gloss: This is the very reason why all of each day he is away from home;

seg.q: êh-pamihtât askiy , ôtêh nihcâyihk êh-kîsikâstêskamawât ayisiyiniwah .
seg.gloss: because he is taking care of the earth, shedding in his course the bright light of day upon the mortal men below.

p.seg: êwakonik aniki kitôtêmak kîtahtawê mâna ka-pîhtokêtisinahkik mînisâpoyah êkwah ayôwinisah , êh-miyihcik kiwîkimâkan , k-êtikot . It is they, your kinsfolk, who ever from time to time are sending into his lodge cookings of berries, and clothing, gifts which your husband and his family receive,” the other told her.

seg.gloss: “Alas, grandmother mine, will you be able to bring me back?”
seg.note: Is this “cî” acting as a preverb?

seg.q: yâ , nôsisê , wiya miskaman mostoso-mêy sisonê sakâhk êh-astêk , kîspin miskaman , kah-kîh-pihkohitin .
seg.gloss: “Yah, my grandchild, if you find the buffalo-dung which lies by the grove, if you find it, I shall be able to bring you back.

p.seg:
êkotah anima êh-pakonêyâk ôma kîsik , êkotah anima êh-ohci-pihkohot mâna kiwîkimâkan , itik ;
nitonah , itik . That is where this sky is pierced, and whence your husband always makes his way,” she told her; “Look for it,” she told her.
êkosi wayawîw , êh-ntonahk . And so she went out and looked for it.
namoya kinwês nôcihtâw , êh-miskahk . It did not take her long to find it.
nitawâpamêw ôhkoma . She went to see her grandmother.
nôhkô , nimiskên ! itik awa nôtokâsiw ôsisima . “Grandmother, I have found it!” the old woman was told by her granddaughter.

seg.gloss: “Now, grandchild, I can help you to escape.

p.seg:
nah ôma , itêw , opîsâkanâpîm ,
nôsisâ , mistikohk tahkopitamôhkan . Take this,” she told her, giving her her rawhide thong, “and tie it, later, to a tree.
êkwah kik-ôsîhtân wacistwan , itah t-âpiyêk kikosis , itik ; But first you will make a nest in which you and your son will sit,” she told her;
itâp anih nôhtêpayikih nipîsâkanâpîm , ta-sipêkipayiw , itik ôhkoma ; “And then, later when my rawhide thong is too short, it will stretch,” her grandmother told her;

seg.q: êkwah nêtê kitaskiy otihtamani , k-âpihkonên anim itah kâ-wîh-pôsiyin .
seg.gloss: “Then when you reach yon earth of yours, you will unti that in which you will be riding.
‘Grandmother, here is your rawhide thong!’ you will say.
You will fling it aloft towards this place.

p.seg: itâp anih ta-pahkihtin ôtê tahkohc , itik . Then it will come falling here,” she told her.
êkosi sipwêhtêw , êkwah êh-ntawih-osîhtât wacistwan . So she went away, first to make the nest.
âsay kiskêyihtam awa pîsim ê-wîh-sipwêhtêyit ôwîkimâkana ; âsay pakwâtam . Then Sun by this time knew that his wife intended to go away; already he felt the grief of it.
mâka nam êskwah kîsi-têtipêwêw ôm âskiy . But he had not yet completed his circuit of the earth.

êkwah awa iskwêw êh-kîsihtât , êh-takopitahk mistikohk , êh-pakitâpêkinisot , âta êh-nôhtêpayiyik , tahkih sîpêkipayiyiw pîsâkanâpiy . Then when the woman had made the thong and had tied it to a tree, and had let herself down by the rope, even though it proved too short, the rawhide thong each time stretched to new length.
êkoyikohk êh-kîsi-têtipêwêt awa pîsim . By this time the Sun had finished his roundabout course.
itohtêw itah k-ôh-pinasiwêyit owîkimâkana . He went to the place from which his wife had let herself down.
otinêw asiniyah . He took up a stone.

hâw , têpiyâhk niwîh-pa-pâhpisihâw niwîkimâkan ! itêw , êkotah ê-nahikâpawit ôma kâ-pakonêyâyik ; “Now then, I shall at least turn the joke on my wife!” he said of her, standing close to that opening;

seg.q: hâw , ostikwânihk ta-pahkisiniyiwa ôh âsiniya niwîkimâkan !
seg.gloss: “Now then, let this stone come down upon my wife's head!

p.seg: namoya nika-pistahwêw pîsimôwâsis nikosis ! itwêw êsah , êh-pakitinât asiniya . Let me not by chance injure Sun-Child, my son!” he said, as he let go the stone.
êkos îsi kîwêw , êh-pîhtokêt . Thereupon he went home and into the lodge.

seg.q: nikosis , kimiskawâw cî , itêh êh-itohtêt nistim ?
seg.gloss: “My son, have you found where my daugher-in-law has gone?”

p.seg: êhag , nikîh-mâtâhwâw itêh êh-itohtêt , êh-kîwêt , itêw . “Yes, I have found her tracks, where she went on her homeward way,” he answered him.
kah ! matwân_cî kwayask ta-pêsiwêw nôsisima ! itêw . “Why! I wonder if really she will succeed in bringing my grandchild safely to her home!” he said to him.

seg.gloss: “Yes!”

p.seg: êh-kîkisêpâyâyik , mwêhcih êkwah ê-wîh-pônêsihk aw iskwêw , êkoyikohk k-âtimikot ôh âsiniya . When early morning had come, just as the woman was about to alight from her fall, even than [sic] that stone overtook her. LB on {ê-wîh-pônêsihk}: Plainly so heard; perhaps {pônêsin} is a different word from the transparent {pônisin}, formed with initial {pôn-}: “cease,” final {-sin}: “come down, fall,” and connective {-i-}.
pahkisiniyiwa ostikwânihk . It came down on her head.
paskipayiyiw pîsâkanâpiy ; pahkisin mohcihk ; nipahisin . The rawhide thong broke; she fell upon the bare ground; she was killed by her fall.
êkosi êkotah pa-pimisin . There she lay.

êkwah awa awâsis êkotah ay-ayâw , êh-nâh-nônihtahisot , âta êh-nipiyit okâwiya . The child stayed there, sucking from time to time at her breast, even though his mother had died. LB ad {êh-nâh-nônihtahisot}: Informant first said {êh-na-nâh-nôhisot}, where {-na-} is a slip of the tongue; in correcting this he substituted the longer derivative verb in the text.
namoya kiskêyihtam êh-nipiyit okâwiya , pisisik êh-ma-mêtawêt êkotah , itah okâwiya ê-pimisiniyit . He did not know that his mother was dead, but kept playing about that place where his mother lay.
piyisk kinwêsk êkotah ayâw . For a long time, in the end, he was there.
piyisk atih-sîkônêsiniyiwa okâwiya . In time his mother's body began to decay where it lay.

kîtahtawê êh-papâmi-ma-mêtawêt , kâ-miskahk itah êh-ayât awa pêyak nôtokêsiw , kâ-wâpahtahk okistikânisiyiwa , nanâtohk kêkwayah êh-kiscikêsiyit . Then at one time, as he went about at his play, he found the place where dwelt a certain little old woman, and he saw her little garden, where in a small way she raised different plants.

namoya kiskêyihtam kêkwayah ôhi awa êwêsis , êkotah mâna êh-ma-mêtawêt , ôhi kiscikânisah êh-mâh-manipitahk , êh-mêtawâkêt , namoya êh-mîcit , kontah êh-mêtawâkêt . The child did not know what they were, but merely would play round there, pulling up the little plants and playing with them, not eating them, but at purposeless play.

êtohtêcih okâwiya , êkoyikohk mâna awa nôtokêsiw otihtam okiscikânisah , konta mâna kâ-pimastêyikih , êh-mâh-manipitamiyit awâsisah , kâ-mâtâhât mâna . When he had gone back to where his mother was, only then would the old woman come to her garden, and there would be her plants lying round, where the child had plucked them up, and then she would see the tracks of him.

pitan âwa wâpamak ! itêyihtam , êh-wawiyatêyimât , êh-apisîsisiyit pakahkam , êh-itêyihtahk . “I wish I could get sight of this rascal!” she thought, finding him droll, seeing that surely he must be a tiny fellow.
kîtahtawê êkwah askamawêw , kîtahtawê kâ-pâpahtâyit awâsisa . So then she lay in wait for him. Presently the child came running. incorrectly merged.
mistahi wawiyatêyimêw , êh-kitimâkinawât . She thought him very droll, and he touched her heart.

êh-pâpahtâyit , êh-otihtamiyit okiscikânisah , mannakisk mâh-manipitamiyiwa , êh-atiwêpinamiyit . As he came running and reached her little plants, without hesitation he began to pluck them up and throw them about.
ka-kitâpamêw , êh-wawiyatêyimât . She kept observing him, and found him lovably droll.
piyisk kisiwâk pêyayâyiwa , ôtah êh-pê-takohtêyit , ôhi êh-mâh-manipitamiyit . At last he had come quite near, walking closer, as he kept uprooting the plants.
môskîstawêw awa nôtokêsiw . The old woman made a dash for him.
iyikohk êh-kiskêyimikot , ê-wîh-tapasiyit , âsay nawatinêw , êh-mamawimoyit êh-kostikot . By the time he perceived her and tried to escape, she had hold of him, as he cried in fear of her.

nôsisimis , nôsisimis ! êh-itât , êh-oy-ocêmât ,
tântêh ômah êh-ohtohtêyin ? itêw . “My little grandchild, my little grandchild!” she said to him, kissing him again and again; “Where do you come from?” she asked him.
ôtah kisiwâk , itik . “Right near here,” he told her.

seg.q: nôsisimis , nama wiya kikisiwâhin , ôhi nikiscikânisah kâ-misi-wanâcihtâyin .
seg.gloss: “My dear little grandchild, I am not angry at you for having spoiled these plants of mine.

p.seg: nawac nimiywêyihtên ê-miskâtân , itêw . I am too glad I have found you,” she told him.
êkosi êh-pakitinât ; sipwêpahtâyiwa . Then, when she set him down, off he ran.
êkwah ay-askôwêw . Then she followed him.
pôtih kâ-wâpahtahk itah êh-pimisiniyit awiya . There she saw someone lying.
êkotah takohtêyiwa . To that place the child went.
kêkway awa , nôsisê ? itêw ; “What person is this, my grandchild?” she asked him;

seg.gloss: “Is this the one of whom you speak as your mother?”

seg.q: hâhag ! kotak mâk âwiyak namoy âwiyak ;
seg.gloss: “Yes! There is not anyone else;

p.seg: êwakw âwa piko êh-nîsiyâhk nikâwiy , itêw . there are just we two, my mother and I,” he told her.

seg.q: hêêy , nôsisimis , mistah êcik ôma êh-kitimâkisiyin , nôsisê !
seg.gloss: “Alas, my dear little grandchild, I see that you are ina woeful plight, my grandchild!
I shall take you home with me.
I shall keep you as my own.

seg.q: namoy âwa êh-pimâtisit kikâwiy , ayis âwa ê-kîh-nipit .
seg.gloss: Yor mother here is not alive; she has died.

seg.q: misawâc piyisk ôtah ka-misi-wanâtisin , êkâ nakatacih .
seg.gloss: You will surely perish here, in the end, if you do not leave her.

p.seg: aspin k-âskîwik nama wîhkâc êkos îspayiw , êkâ êh-pimâtisit ta-kîh-wîc-âyâmiht , itêw ; Never since this earth began has it been so, has it been possible for one not living to be stayed by,” she told him;
kâ-kîwêhtahitin , itêw . “I shall take you home with me,” she told him.

seg.gloss: “Yes!”

p.seg: tâpwê kiwê-wîcêwêw ôsisima . Really she took her grandchild home with her.
takohtahêw wîkihk . She brought him to her dwelling.
hây , kitimâkêyimêw ; kitimâkinawêw , êh-asamât . Oh, she felt sorry for him; she pitied him and gave him food.
miywêyihtam awa nâpêsis , êkwah êh-wîcêwât nôtokêsiwa . The little boy liked being with the old woman.
êkosi êkwa pônêyimêw okâwiya . And so he ceased thinking of his mother.

kîtahtawêh itah êh-ay-ayâcik ôhkoma ,
nôsisê , tahk ôma mâna nipapâmohtân . Then, presently, as he and his grandmother were living there, “Grandson, I am in the habit of always walking about here.

seg.gloss: Do you never go off anywhere.

p.seg: kanawêyihtah mâna kîkinaw , âskaw kit-êtohtêyin nikistikânisihk , itêw ôsisima . Always stay and take care of the house, and from time to time go to my garden,” she told her grandson.

tâpwê kîtahtawê êh-kîsikâyik ,
nôsisê , niwîh-papâmohtân , itêw ,
êh-ntonamân mâna ta-mîciyân , itêw ,
mîna âskaw êh-itohtêyân ôtê oskinîkiwak êh-wîkicik wâhyawês , itik . And really, when day came, “Grandson, I am going to walk about,” she told him, “to look for things to eat,” she told him, “and to go, as I do from time to time, to where some young men live, not very far from here,” she told him.

êkosi mân ê-sipwêhtêyit , êkwah mâna wiya êkotah êh-kîskwêt , âskaw okstikânisiyihk êh-itohtêt , kâh-itohtêci kontah êh-mâh-manipitahk mâna okiscikânisiyiwa . So she would always go away, and he would play there, going sometimes to her garden, and when he went there, pulling up his grandmother's plants.

wêtâkosiki , têkosihki awa nôtokêsiw ,
nôsisê , kikîh-itohtân cî nikiscikânisihk ?
êhag , êtikocih , êkos êh-itohtêt , konta mâna kâ-pimastêyikih okiscikânisah , êh-mâh-manipitamiyit . In the evening, when the old woman came, “Grandchild, did you go to my garden?” and when he said, “Yes,” she would go there, and there her plants would be lying scattered about, where he had pulled them up.

nôsisimis tâpwê ê-kâkêpâtisit ! itwê mâna awa nôtokêsiw , êh-pâhpit mâna , êh-môskinahk , êh-kîwêhtatât . “Truly my little grandson is naughty!” the old woman would say, and she would laugh, as she picked them up and carried them home.

piyîhtokêci , k-ôtinât mâna , êh-oy-ocêmât ,
nôsisimis , nôsisimis ! êh-itât mâna . When she came into the lodge, she would pick him up and kiss him again and again, saying, “My dear little grandson, my dear little grandson!”
kîtahtawê kâ-kakwêcimât ôhkomah , êkwah êh-misikitit . Then at one time he began to ask his grandmother questions, we he had grown larger.

nôhkô , kêkwayah ôhi ? itêw , nîswayak wîhkwâhk êy-asiwatêyikih , êh-tahkopitêyikih apasôhk . “Grandmother, what sort of things are these?” he asked her, of some things that were enclosed in two separate bladders that were tied to the lodge-poles.
hâ , nôsisê , kont ânihi , itik . “Why, grandson, never mind what they are,” she answered him.
namoya wîh-wîhtamawêw kêkwayah ôhi k-âsiwatêyikih . She would not tell him what things were in there.
mâka kiskêyihtam awa pîsimôwâsis êh-waskawipayiyikih mân ôhi wîhkwayah . But Sun-Child knew that those bladders were always twitching and moving.

êkosi êkota êh-ay-ayâcik , kîtahtawêh êkwa mâka mîna ê-sipwêhtêyit ôhkomah , kâ-kimotamawât ocascisimisiyiw , êy-osihtât tâpakwânan . And so, as they lived there, once when his grandmother had gone off in her usual way, he filched her little sinew strings and made some snares. CHECK tapakwanan

êh-kîsihtât , tahtwayak êh-pîkopayiyik owîkisiwâw , akotah êh-tâpakwêt , êkwah ispimihk êh-kipahahk wîkiwâw . When he had made them, wherever their little dwelling was broken, he set a snare, and at the top he closed up the smoke-hole of their lodge.
êkwah pêyak ôma wîhkway kâ-pôskosahk , kontah kâ-sâkaskinêyit cahcahkayiwah . Then, when he had cut open one of those bladders, there, it was full of blackbirds.
êkotôwahk ês ôhi k-âsiwasoyt . So these it was were in there.
kont ê-sâkôwêt , êh-nôcihât , hâtah kâ-wîh-wayawîhâyit , kahkiyaw tâpakwâtêw . He whooped and yelled, and chased them, and try as they might to fly out of the house, he snared them all.
mêscihêw , kontah êh-tatâhpit , êkwah êh-mêtawâkêt êyakonih . He killed them all, laughing loud and amusing himself with them.

iyikohk ,
ta-takohtêw , êh-itêyimât ôhkomah , êkwah pêyakwayak asahêw , êh-akwanahwât ,
êkwah kê-môwâyâhkok , êh-akwanahât , êh-itwêt ; When he thought his grandmother was about to arrive, he piled them up in one place and threw something over them, and as he put them under the covering, “Now we shall eat them,” he said; LB ad {êh-akwanahât}: If this is correctly recorded, informant was hesitating between two words {akwanahêw} (for older {-ahyêw}): “he places him covering” and {akwanahwêw}: “he covers him with something, or by tool.” The latter is attested by the occurrence of the corresponding form with inanimate object, {akwanaham}, and of other derivatives; not so the former, whose inanimate would end in {-astêw}.
êkwah kê-môwâyâhk nôhkom , itwêw . “Now we shall eat them, my grandmother and I,” he said.

iyikohk êh-takohtêyit , êh-otâkosiniyik , êh-pîhtokêyit , ômis îtêw :
nôhkô , êkwah ka-mîcisonânaw , itêw . When she arrived, in the evening, and came into the lodge he said to her, “Grandmother, now we shall eat.”
kîkway awa kâ-wih-ayâtamihit nôsisimis ? itik . “What will this dear little grandchild of mine be giving me as a treat?” she asked him.

seg.gloss: “Just uncover this here, grandmother.”

p.seg: êh-pâskinahk , awîn ôhi câhcâhkayôwa ! When she uncovered it, what did she see but the blackbirds!
êh-kîskwêyit êyikohk , êkwah otinêyiwa , êh-paskopitêyit . When at last she ceased her lamentation, she picked them up and plucked them.
êh-kîsihâyit , êkwah pakâsimêyiwa . When she had got them clean, she set them to cook.

êh-kîsiswâyit ,
nôsisê , kiya piko mîcisoh , itik . When she had cooked them done, “Grandson, do you alone eat,” she told him.
tâpwê wiya piko ma-mîcisôw . Accordingly, he alone partook of the meal.
iyikohk êh-kîspot , pôni-môwêw . When he had his fill, he quit eating them.
ahêyiwa . She put them away.
itap kîhtwâm mîna ka-môwâwak , itik . “You will eat some more of them later,” she told him.

êkos êh-ay-ayâcik mîn êkotah , tahto-kîsikâw ê-sipwêhtêyit ôhkomah , iyikoh mîna êh-kitamwât ôhih cahcahkayôwa , âsay mîna tâpakwêw . So, as they continued to live there, and his grandmother went off every day, when he had eaten all of those blackbirds, again he set snares.

êkwah mîna ispimihk êh-kipahahk wîkiwâw , âsay mîna ôma wîhkway pôskosam , kontah kâ-kitôyit ômîcaskosîsah , konta mâna kâ-sâkôwât , êh-nôcihât . Again he closed up their lodge at the top, and again he cut open a bladder, and the place was filled with the twittering of swallows, as he whooped and yelled and gave them chase.
tahtoh kâ-wîh-wayawiyâmocik , tâpakwâtêw . As many of them as tried to escape from the house, he snared.
mêscihêw mâka mîna . He killed them all, this time too.
âsay mîna pêyakwanohk asahêw , êh-akwanahwât . Again he piled them up in one place and covered them up.
êkoyikohk kâ-takohtêyit ôhkomah . Then his grandmother came home.

ômis îtêw :
nôhkô , êkwa mîna ka-mîcisonânaw , itêw . He said to her, “Grandmother, now we shall eat again,” he told her.
kîkway awa kâ-wîh-atamihit nôsisim ? itêw awa nôtokêsiw . “What treat is this grandson of mine about to give me?” the old woman asked him.
êyakw ânima pâskinah , itêw ôhkoma . “Uncover this here,” he said to his grandmother.
êh-pâskinahk , sêmâk êkwa mâtoyiwa . When she uncovered it, at once she began to weep.
hâ , nôhkô , kiyâm api ! konta mâna kimâton ! itêw . “Oh, grandmother, be quiet! You are always weeping for no reason at all!” he said to her.

êh-kîskowêyit , ômis îtik :
nôsisê , tapwê mistahi kikakêpâtisin . When she ceased crying, she said to him, “Grandson, surely you are very naughty.

seg.gloss: It was because you were in a miserable state that I took pity on you and befriended you, and here you are doing away with all my children!
These are my children, grandson.
[no translation] [Go away.]
In the end I may be led to do you some harm.

seg.q: kikisiwâhin , êkwah êh-âta-kitimâkêyimitân , iyikohk kâ-kîsinâcihiyin , nikiscikânisah mîna mistah ê-misi-wanâcihtâyan ;
seg.gloss: You have angered me, even though I felt pitying kindness for you when you did me harm and greatly laid waste my garden-plants;
I loved and cherished these my poor children whom you have all destroyed.
Be off; go away!

p.seg: kimanâkitimahitin , êh-kitimâkisiyin , itik . I do not want to bring you to ruin, poor creature that you are,” she said to him.
êkosi pasikôw , êh-wayawît , ê-sipwêhtêt . Accordingly, he arose, went out of the lodge, and departed.
kontah pikw îtê isi sipwêhtêw . He went off in some direction, he knew not whither.
itah êh-tipiskâyik , kontah kawisimôw . Wherever he was at nightfall, he lay down, not choosing where.
êh-wâpaniyik , sipwêhtêw . When day broke, he went on.
êh-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik , kâh-wâpahtahk mîkiwâhp , itah mitoni êh-ay-âhkwacâwahkâsiyik . At noon he saw a tipi in a place where there were many small ravines.
êkotah itohtêw . Thither he went.
pôt ôma kî-masinahikâtêyiw mîkiwâhp . He saw that the tipi was covered with painted symbols.

êh-takohtêt ,
hâhâ , tawâw , tawâw , pîsimôwâsis ! kâ-matwê-itwêyit oskinîkiwa . When he reached it, “Oho, come in, come in, Sun-Child!” a young man called out to him.

êh-pîhtokêt , awîn ôhi , kî-wâsakâmêpiyiwa oskinîkiwa , mitoni ê-mâh-miyohoyit , osâm piko pêhpêsâpowayâna êh-wiyâhtamiyit . When he entered, what did he see byt some youths sitting round the sides of the lodge, splendidly dressed, but wearing only striped robes!
ôtêh ohci ! êh-itikot , namoya tâpwêhtawêw . When “Over here!” they said to him, he did not heed their invitation.
ôtah kiyâm ! itêw , skwâhtêmihk ê-nahapit . “This will do, right here!” he answered them, seating himself by the door-flap.

kîtahtawê ,
hayâ , wêsâ nama mayaw kitasamâwâw pîsimôwâsis ! Then soon, “Dear me, we are indecently slow about serving food to Sun-Child!
miywâsinôpan êh-otihtikoyahk ! k-êtwêyit . And just now we thought it so glad an event that he came to us!” said one.

seg.gloss: “Goodness, but what can we give him to eat?”

seg.q: cêh , kîpah ta-kîsitêk wînâstakay nawacîk ! ta-kîsitêw .
seg.gloss: “Why, quickly roast a buffalo-stomach to be served well done and piping hot! Quickly roast it done.”

p.seg: tâpwê nawacîw . So one put on the roast.
kiyipah akwânamiyiwa . Very soon he took it from the fire.
yahô , matwân_cîw oma kîsitêw ! itwêyiwa ; “Dear me, surely it cannot be done!” said another;

seg.gloss: “You had better bite off a piece to try!
Surely you will find it can't be cooked done!”

p.seg: êyôko mîna paskêhtam . He too bit off a piece.

namoya kîsitêw , itwêw mîn êyako ,
mâcikôtân ! “It is not done,” said this one too; “Just see for yourself!”
kotakah miyêw , ohpimê êh-ati-paskêhtahkik . He gave it to another, and each took a bite next to where the other had bitten.
piyisk wâsakâmê-paskêhtamwak ôkô oskinîkiwak . When they got through, these youths had bitten off morsels all round the edge of the gizzard.

âsa nâha nôtokêsiw pê-sipwêhtêw , awa pîsimôwâsis ka-pêh-nakatât nôtokêsiwa , ê-kiskêyihtahk êh-otihtâyit otawâsimisah pîsimôwâsisah . By this time yonder old woman had set out to come here, the old woman from whom Sun-Child had parted when he came, for she knew that Sun-Child had reached her sons' abode.
êyokw ês âna nôtokêsiw ôhih otawâsimisah oskinîkiwa kâ-mitâtasiyit . For these ten youths were that old woman's sons.
piyisk kahkiyaw ôk ôskinîkiwak paskêhtamwak . At last all the youths had taken bites.
kîsitêw ôma , itwêwak . “It is cooked done,” they said.
âh , êkos îsi asamihk ! itêwak pîsimôwâsisah . “Ho, so now let him eat!” they said of Sun-Child.
otinam môhkomân , wâsakâm êh-wâskasahk oma wînâstakay . He took his knife and cut all around the edge of the stomach.
êh-kîsi-manisahk , sisikoc matostêwêpinam . When he had pared off the edge, suddenly he threw the trimming into the fire.

êkos îsi wayawiyâmot ,
kimêscihikonaw pîsimôwâsis
k-êtwêyit . At once he fled out of the lodge, as they cried, “Sun-Child is killing us all!”
tâpwê kahkiyaw nipahêw . Indeed, he had killed thm all.
sîsîkwêyiwa ês ôhi . For they were rattlesnakes. CHECK sisikweyiwa

mêscihêw . He had done away with them all. Characteristic obscure passage of the type not due to extraneous difficulties of dictation or recording. One or more causes may be at work, such as laziness, fatigue, impatience at the slow pace of dictation, obstructive attitude toward the recorder, desire to withhold information from the foreigner, actual tabu, or traditional omission. Probably the last-named was here operative; informant had heard the story told in this way and would not add to it. For he could not be induced to dictate the explanation which he voluntarily gave: The rattlesnake-youths have left each a poison-fang in the edge of the maw, to kill Sun-Child when he eats. By throwing their fangs into the fire he kills the rattlesnakes.
êkosi tapasîw . And so he fled.
êkosi nâha nôtokêsiw pê-nawaswêw , pîsimôwâsisah êh-pimitisahwât . And now yonder old woman came in pursuit, chasing Sun-Child.

seg.q: êkwah anih kikisiwahin , pîsimôwâsis , mitoni kâ-kitimahiyin , nitawâsimisak êkwah êh-mêscihacik !
seg.gloss: “Now you have really angered me, Sun-child, doing me so many griefs and now destroying all my sons!”

p.seg: êkos îsy êkwah nawaswâtik êkwah nôtokêsiwa , pikw îtê êh-itâmot . So now he was chased by the old woman, and fled he knew not where.
kîtahtawê kisiwâk êkwah êh-askôkot , êkwah sêkihik . In time, when she was close upon him, he became frightened.

omis îtwêw :
nôhtâh , kisiwâk pimohtê ! He cried, “Father, come near in your course!
niwîh-nipahik sîsîkwêw nôtokêsiw ! itêw . The Old Rattlesnake Woman means to kill me!” he said to him.
tâpwê capasis pimohtêyiwa ôhtâwiya pîsimwa . Truly, low in his course came his father, the Sun.
mistahi kisitêyiw , piyisk ê-wîh-kîsisot awa nôtokêsiw . It grew very hot, until at last the old woman felt herself about to be roasted.
pôyôw . She gave up.
êkos ânih ê-pmâtisiyan , pîsimôwâsis ! kipônihitin , itik ; “And so you have saved your life, Sun-Child! I give you up,” she said to him;

mâka êkotah ohci êkâ wiya , êkâya wîhkâc mostâhtak nahapih ! itêw awa nôtokêsiw pîsimôwâsisah . “But owing to this, do not, do never seat yourself on the bare ground!” said the old woman to Sun-Child.
tâpwê nawac ispimihk pimohtêyiwa ôhtâwiya . Accordingly, his father went higher in his course.
kîwêw awa nôtokêsiw . The old woman went home.
êkwah awa pîsimôwâsis ê-pimohtêt , miskawêw asiniya êh-napakâpiskisiyit . And Sun-Child, as he walked on, found a stone of flat shape.
otinêw êyakoni , itah ê-wîh-nahapit , êkotah êh-ahât , êh-anâskasot ôh âsiniyah . He took it up, and wherever he meant to sit down, there he placed it, using that stone as a seat.

tahkih êkosi tôtam , mîna ê-wîh-nipât , êh-anâskasot asiniya , wiyâpaniyiki , sêpwêhtêci , êh-pimiwihât asiniya . He did this every time, putting the stone under him also when he went to sleep, and in the morning, when he went on, taking the stone with him.
kîtahtawê ôma êh-papâmâcihot , kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahk ôtênaw . Then at one time, ash he wandered about, he came upon a town.
êkotah takosin . He reached it.
ispatinâhk nîpawiw , êh-kitâpahtahk ôhi mîkiwâhpah . He stood on a rise in the land and looked at the tents.
yahô , pîsimôwâsis takosin ! itwêwân . “Oho, Sun-Child has arrived!” was said in his hearing.
âsay pêyak pêy-itohtêyiwa , êh-pê-ntomikot . Soon one came to him, to invite him in.

seg.gloss: “Ho, Sun-Child, you are to come!”
“Oh, very well.”

p.seg: wîcêwêw . He went along with him.

êh-pîhtokêt mîkiwâhpihk ,
nhâ , ta-tawâw ! itâw . As he entered the lodge, “Oh, come in!” he was told.

êh-nahapit ,
hâ , asamihk kiyipa ! nôhtêhkatêtokê ! itâw . When he sat down, “There, quickly give him food! Surely he must be hungry!” was said of him.

seg.gloss: “Why, gracious heavens, it is Sun-Child!

seg.q: âyiman ani itah kâ-takohtêyin pisisik êh-mêtawêhk , êh-manitôwi-mêtawêhk .
seg.gloss: Truly it is no light thing that you have come here, where unceasing are the contests, the contests of spirit-animals.
And indeed, it is we who are always defeated.
By this time doubtless he has already decided to challenge you, the Iron Bull.
seg.note: LB ad {pîwâpisko-mostos}: Error; the beast is a bear, below.

seg.gloss: Most dangerous is he; never have we defeated him.

p.seg: êkosi âta sâkwêyimoyâhkoh , ôhcitaw nika-misi-wanâcihikonân , itwêyiwa . And so, no matter how unwilling we are to contend, he is determined to destroy us completely,” the other explained.
namoya êh-papâ-mêtawêyân , itêw . “I do not happen to be going about in search of contests,” he told him.

seg.gloss: “Doubtless they will challenge you none the less.

p.seg: awiya mastaw kâ-takosiniyit , sêmâk mawinêhwêwak , itâw ; They challenge at once any new arrival,” he was told;

seg.gloss: “But it is evening now.

p.seg: wâpahki mâskôc ka-mawinêhokwak , itâw . Tomorrow probably they will challenge you,” he was told.
êkosi êkwah asamâw . Then he was given food.
piyisk tipiskâyiw . At last darkness fell.
êyokô kîksêpê , ê-kih-mîcisocik , sâsay kâ-têpwêwiht . Then, the next morning, when they had eaten, already he heard the announcing call.

seg.gloss: “Hear ye, hear ye, hear ye! Make ready!
Come to look on!
there will be a contest!

seg.q: êh-papâ-mêtawêt , êh-itwêhk , kâ-takohtêt otâkosihk pîsimôwâwâsis , wîh-mêtawêw pîwâpisko-maskwa !
seg.gloss: Last night arrived Sun-Child, who, it is said, is going about seeking contests; he is to contend with the Iron Bear!
Come forth!”

p.seg: âsay pê-tohtêyiwa . Already the other had come.

seg.gloss: “Come, Sun-Child, you are to come forth, as the Iron Bear is to challenge you.”

p.seg:
êkosi ,
hâw , êyiwêhk wawêyî . Then, “at any rate, go forth.

misawâc âta êkâ tâpwêhtamani , ohcitaw ka-kakwê-misi-wanâcihik , itik ôhi wîkiyihk kâ-pîhtokêt , ôm îtah k-âpit . In any case, even if you pay no heed, none the less he will seek to destroy you,” he was told by him into whose lodge he had come, where now he stayed.

seg.gloss: “Very well.

p.seg: êyiwêhk mâka , itwêw . “but never mind,” he said.
êkos êh-wawêyît . Accordingly, he made ready.
sâsay itah ê-tahtakwahcâsiyik , êkotah êy-itohtêyit . Already, where there was a stretch of level land, thither the other had gone.
hâ , kiyipa pê-wayawî ! itâw . “Ho, quickly, come forth!” he was told.
êkosi wayawîw , êh-itohtêt . Accordingly, he went out and proceeded to the place.
sâsay wîhkwêkâpawiyiwa . They were already standing about in a circle.

êh-takohtêt ,
haw , pîsimôwâsis , kipapâ-mêtawân , kitikawin . When he arrived, “Now then, Sun-Child, you are going about engaging in contests, it is said concerning you.

seg.gloss: You shall have the first shot.”

seg.q: namoya ! kiyawâw nîkân ! êkâ_mâ niya wêh-mêtawêyân .
seg.gloss: “No! You first! Seeing it is not of my own will I am contending.”

p.seg: êêg , itwêw awa wâkayôs . “Very well,” said that bear.

âsay ômis îtêyihtam :
hâw , nôhtâ , kisiwâk ohcih kanawêyimin ! itwêw , ômisi êh-itêyihtah :
mâskôc kisâstêkih , ta-nayawapit , êh-itêyihimât ôhi wâkayôsa . Already he thought as follows: “Now, O my father, watch me from close by!” he said, thinking this: “Perhaps, if the weather is hot, he will tire,” thinking this of the bear.
tâpwê ati-kisitêyiw , êh-ati-kisâstêyik . Really, it grew hotter and hotter, as the bright glow of the sun increased.

seg.gloss: “Now then, from yon place I shall come.

p.seg: nêwâw ka-wâyônistâtn ; mwêhci nêwâw êkotah nka-pimakocinin , ê-wih-otihtinikot , ê-wih-kakwê-nipahikot . Four times I shall start for you; and on the fourth time I shall spring,” meaning that he would seize him, that he would try to kill him.
mâka kisitêyiw . But it was very hot.
mistahih ati-sipwêhtêw awa wâkayôs , êkotê êy-ohci-pê-sipwêhtêt , êh-pê-nâtât pîsimôwâsisah . The bear went off a long ways, starting from a good distance to come running at Sun-Child.
tâpiskôc êh-yôskahcâyik , êh-pê-pimohtêyit , êyikohk êh-kotâwahcinamiyit . Just as if the ground were soft swamp, when he came, he sank deep into it.
kisiwâk êy-ihtâyit , wayôniyiwa . When he was near he turned back.
mîna êkotêh ohci pê-sipwêhtêyiwa . Again he started from the same place.
ayiwâkês êkwah iskoskiwêyiwa . This time he sank even farther into the ground.
mîna kisiwâk êy-ihtâyit , wayôniyiwa . Again, when he had come near, he turned back.
âsay mîna pê-sipwêhtêyiwa , tahk âyiwâk êy-iskoskiwêyit . Again he started hither, always sinking deeper into the earth.
kêyâpic wayôniyiwa êkwah , êkotah êkwah ka-kakwê-nipahikot . Now he turned back once more, and now was when he would try to kill him.
mâka sâsay mistahi nayawapiyiwa . But by this time he was very tired.
ispih kisiwâk êkwah êh-ayâyit , pisisik pîwâpisk isinâkosiyiwa . When he was near, he looked as though all of iron.

kontah ê-sâkôwêwiht ,
êkwah miyâmay wi-pê-kwaskwêpayihôw ! êh-itêyihtahk , Those on his side were yelling wildly. “Now surely he will come leaping!” he thought.

ôhih owîcêwâkanah itah kâ-kîh-pîhtokêt êyakoni ,
âhkamêyimoh ! tahkih êh-itikot , êkwah êh-pê-kwaskwêpayihoyit , kawipayihôw . His comrade at whose house he was staying kept telling him to take heart. And then, as the other came leaping, he flung himself down on the ground.
nama wâpamik . The other did not see him.

iyâtah-isi-kwâskwêpayihôyit , itah kâ-kîh-nîpawit , âsay itêh k-ôhtohtêyit , êkotê âsay nîpawiw awa wâkayôs , êh-kwêskipayihot . In vain the other tried to hurl himself to the spot whence he had stood; already he stood there when the other had come, throwing himself from place to place. LB ad {wâkayôs}: Slip of tongue; it is Sun-Child who stands there; so translated.
pôtih kîh-nîpawiyiwa . Then he saw the other stand still.
êkos ê-môskîstawât . At once he attacked him.

wâh-otihtâcih , êh-kawipayihoyit , namoya wâpamêw , konta mâna kâ-sâkôwêwiht owîcêwâkana pîsimôwâsis , êh-miywêyihtamiyit ôhi êh-mêtawâkâtât . When the other, as soon as he was upon him, flung himself down, he could not see him; wildly all this time his companions were whooping for Sun-Child, happy that he was giving that other a fight.
piyisk wîh-nipahatâhtamiyiwa . At last the other was helpless from want of breath.
ôki mîna ayisiyiniwak mâkôhkasôwak , osâm kisiwâk êh-ayâyit pîsimwa . Those men, too, were oppressed by the heat, for the Sun was too near.
piyisk pêyakwanohk nîpawiw awa wâkayôs , ê-wîh-nipahatâhtahk . At last he stood still in one place, that bear, almost dead from want of breath.

piyisk êkwah otinam wîpisisah , nêhi nôtokêsiwa kâ-kîh-ohpikihikot êwakoni ê-kîh-osîhtwâkot . So then he took his arrows, which that little old woman who had raised him had made for him. CHECK osihtwakot

êh-tâwaciyit awa wâkayôs , ê-wîh-nipahatâhtahk , êyakoni kâ-pimwât otôniyihk ; ayisk êkotah pikoh namoya pîwâpiskôwiyiwa . Where that bear stood with open mouth, helplessly panting, he shot him in the mouth; for only there was the other not of iron.

aspin êh-pîhtokêhâyit kêhkêhkwah , ê-sâpowêyawîhâyit , otêhiyiw êh-ati-tahkonamiyit , ka-sâkôwêwiht owîcêwâkanah pîsimôwâsis . In flew a hawk, flying clear through the creature's body, seizing his heart, while Sun-Child's companions cheered him.

seg.q: hâw , pîsimôwâsis , ôtêh âpihtaw-kîsikâhk isi kwahkonin .
seg.gloss: “Very well, Sun-Child, throw me in the direction of noon.

p.seg:
êkotê ,
êh-pîwâpiskôwit wâkayôs nkitimâkêyimik , itwêci ayisiyiniw cêkwah kâ-wih-ohpikit , ta-tâpwêw , itwêw . There, when mortal man, who in time is to grow forth, says, ‘The Iron Bear has taken pity on me,’ he will speak true,” said he.
hêy , isi-kawipayihô ! itêw . “Ho, throw yourself to the ground facing so!” he told him.
êkos isi-kawipayihôyiwa . So the other threw himself to the ground, facing that way.

ômis îtwêw :
niwîcêwâkanitik , êkâ wiya nipahihkok k-âstwâkawiyêk , itêw ; Thus he spoke: “My comrades, do not kill those who have been given as stakes by your opponents,” he told them; CHECK ?? kâ-astâkêwiyêk, a 2p relational on VAI astâkê ‘use as stakes’? Or, as above, an impersonal of an unlisted VTA
tahkih êkosi tôtamêko , namoya ta-kîh-ohpikiw ayisiyiniw , itêw ; “If you always do thus, mortal man will not be able to grow forth,” he told them;
êkosi ka-pônihtânâwâw kâ-mêtawêyêk , itêw . “In this wise you are to cease from your contests,”
êkosi tâpwê ! itwêyiwa owîcêwâkana . “Truly, that is right!” said his companions.

otiyinîmiwâwa ês ôki mâna ê-kîh-astwâtocik , mâka ê-sâkôcihât , k-ôh-kitahamawât , tâpwêhtâk . For in fact these people were accustomed to stake their followers; but now that he had overcome them and prohibited it, they obeyed him.
namoy âwiya êkwah ta-kîh-mawinêhokot , êkonih piko êh-mantôwiyit kâ-sâkôcihât . there was no one now who could challenge him, since he had defeated the one among them who had most spirit power.
êkosi wêtinah êkwah êh-ayâcik ôk âyisiyiniwak . So now these people lived in peace.

kîtahtawê êh-sipwêhtêt , ispatinâhk ê-nahapit , wani-kiskisiw asiniyah mâna êh-anâskasot . Then at one time, as he went forth and sat down on a hilltop, he forgot to follow his custom of using the stone as a seat.

kîtahtawê kâ-môsihât êh-kwayasitêyit ôtêh , itah k-ôh-mîsit , kinêpikwah sîsîkwêwa , nêhi kâ-kîh-mêscihimât otawâsimisiyiwa nôtokêsiwa , êyakoni êh-tôtâkot . Presently he felt something crawl in here, [no translation] a rattlesnake; it was yon old woman whose children he had wiped out, was doing this to him.

ayis ,
êkêya wîhkâc mostâhtak apih ! kîh-itik . For, “Never sit on the bare ground!” she had told him.
êkwah êh-âta-kakwê-pihkohât , nama kîh-pihkohêw . Then, try as he might to get the creature out, he could not get it out.
piyisk owîcêwâkanah otihtik . At last his comrades came to where he was.

ôma êh-mâkohikot , ê-wîh-nipahikot , piyisk mihcêtiwân itah oma k-âyât , tahkih ê-sîhkimikot ta-kakwê-nipahât ôhi sîsîkwêwa , osâm êh-miywêyimikot ôh âyisiyiniwa . As thus he was tormented by that creature which was trying to kill him, at last many came to where he was, urging him to try to kill that rattlesnake, for dearly those people loved him.
ôtê piyisk ostikwânihk asiwasoyiwa . at last it got into his head here.
êkwah ôtê êkwah wîh-kâh-kîskwêw , ê-wîh-nipahikot . And when it was here, he began to be delirious, as it was killing him.
kêkway omôhkomân ntotam . He asked for something to use in the way of a knife.
miyâw . It was given to him.
êkwah êh-manisahk ôtah , ê-wîh-kakwê-pakonêhahk ostikwân , piyisk pakonêham . Then he cut a piece away from here, trying to make a hole in his head, and at last succeeded.
hâw , nôhtâ , nimâkohik ; niwîh-nipahik sîsîkwêw ! kisiwâk pimohtê ! itêw ôhtâwiya . “Here, father, the rattlesnake is tormenting me and means to kill me! Come near to me!” he said to his father.
tâpwê kisiwâk ayâyiwa . Really, the latter came near.
ôki ayisiyiniwak pinasiwêwak , osâm mistah êh-kisisocik . Those people went down from the hill-top, because they were too hot.
kîtahtawê ka-wayawiyâhtawiyit , êh-nipayihkasôyit . Presently it came climbing out, forced to extremity by the heat.
êkosi pimâtisiw . So his life was saved.
êkwah ôma ostikwân ômis isi sinikonahk , iyiniwiw . Then, when he rubbed his head like this, it healed.

êkoyikohk ôhtâwiya êkotah kâ-nîpawiyit ,
êhêhêhê haha ! êh-itikot ; Then, there stood his father, saying to him, “Alas and alas!

seg.q: ayisk kîh-kakêpâtisiw kikâwiy , kâ-kîh-sipwêhtahisk , êkâ awiyak k-ôh-kakêskimisk , kâ-papâ-misi-wanâtahkamikisiyin , k-ôh-kakêpâtisiyin .
seg.gloss: No wonder, seeing how foolish was your mother who took you away with her, so that there was no one to instruct you, no wonder that you went about making a ruin of things at large, and that you are a fool.
You will continue to make a greater and greater mess of things, my son.
It will be better if I take you home with me.
You are too much of a fool.
If you continue to go about as you have, no good will come of it.

p.seg: namoya êkosi nitisi-nôcihtân , itik . I do not wish such things to be,” his father told him.
êkos êh-kîwêcik , ispimihk wîkiyihk êh-itohtahikot , aspin omosôma êh-wîkimât . So they went home, his father taking him aloft to where he dwelt; and from that time on he stayed with his grandfather.
êkoyikohk êskwâk âtayôhkêwin . That is the end of the sacred story. LB: Informant adds that Sun-Child was turned into the Morning Star.
